body:
The synoptic gospels (Mark, Matthew, and Luke) as they're both the least corrupted and contain quotations from Jesus himself. Most of Christianity will try to steer you away from them in favor of other writings that are easier to twist, but that's the devil doing his work as always.

Also don't put 100% faith in your English print. Even the most accurate ones are known to make subtle changes or "guess" something with zero indication that they did so. You might want to check out an interlinear and even check that against the actual words because I've even seen interlinears be corrupted. Don't bother buying anything else, they're free online.

And it's important for me to add, don't go blindly believing everything out there labeled "Christian", and that includes people and denominations who usually agree with you. That's such a common tendency these days, I used to do that full-time myself. Too many people just listen to what some guy on a podcast says and some political articles on the internet and nothing else.

post.body:
...ἐγένετο ῥῆμα Θεοῦ ἐπὶ Ἰωάννην...

...a statement of God became upon John...

Needless to say this is quite confusing. But it looks to be taken from the Hebrew gospel, which because it is such a common phrase and fits the context here perfectly, almost certainly said:

הָיְתָה רוּחַ אֱלֹהִים עַל־יֹוחָנָן

the **spirit** of God became upon John

Now that actually makes sense. And implies that John's following statements are prophetic and not merely his ramblings.

Then how do the vast majority of people end up with the same sexual attraction and the same knowledge and desire of sexual intercourse? How do animals know to have sex, and compete for it?

> Oh man, you are watching *way* too much porn.

I don't watch any porn, it's a well-known aspect of biology: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Male_expendability

body:
> It is true. Genesis 19:6 and the mob were outside the house and couldn't get in, that's why they were shouting for Lot to let them in.

They were giving him a chance to do it "the easy way". Otherwise they'd have done it "the hard way".

> Yeah, so? Two strangers are more important than your own children? Lot called them "Lords", so he probably knew they were angels and they could look after themselves. But even if he didn't, well, there is only so far you can go to protect others. Your own children come first.

It's a story. Perhaps one of the people who adapted it lived in a time when it was not viewed as wrong for fathers to treat their children and grandchildren like property, especially daughters. Perhaps even Lot himself. Very wrong but easy for our groupthink-minded nature to overlook when everyone else does it too.

Also treating people differently because of their biological relation to you is condemned multiple times by Jesus. As we are all one family.

> Right. And the lesson here is that the raping women is fine, killing the unborn, babies, children, and women is fine, and that the Bible's morality is poison.

The earliest references to Sodom and Gomorrah (before Genesis was written) all agree that its primary evil was inhospitality. They were selfish, violent, and greedy. The lesson is that this is deserving of death, but God is faithful and will save you if you only listen. It's much the same as Noah.

The earliest references to Sodom and Gomorrah (before Genesis was written) all agree that its primary evil was inhospitality. They were selfish, violent, and greedy. The lesson is that this is deserving of death, but God is faithful and will save you if you only listen. It's much the same as Noah.

Yeah, so? Two strangers are more important than your own children? Lot called them "Lords", so he probably knew they were angels and they could look after themselves. But even if he didn't, well, there is only so far you can go to protect others. Your own children come first.

Besides, the whole story is just so childish. *Every* man in the city, young and old, came to Lot's house to rape the angels. Not just "a mob", but every single man in the whole city.

> Remember most of these stories are probably made up or adapted to teach a lesson

Right. And the lesson here is that the raping women is fine, killing the unborn, babies, children, and women is fine, and that the Bible's morality is poison.

post.body:
So recently Kim Jong Un came out and told his board that they're running out of food. As usual, the commentary was all mindless ridicule and condemnation of the DPRK.

Now, why is there a food shortage in Korea? Well it's because any nation that is 'juche,' that has to rely upon its own resources is going to experience an unsteady supply of animal products and agriculture. Sometimes there is a drought. Sometimes locusts. That's how it is.

So, the westerners laugh at the Koreans, and they call Kim an evil leader, and yet their governments are the ones who actively refuse to have any kind of trade relations. Yes, the same people who will use this as some kind of gotcha literally are responsible for the families that must now endure rationing.

Now, why do they do this to them? Well it's because they're not liberal and they're socialists. Westerners have this really arrogant belief that anything outside of liberal egalitarianism and a free market is dumb, inferior, and essentially evil. That, we have to endlessly bomb the Middle East because they practice a conservative theocracy. Or, we have to 'quarantine' Cuba because they wanted Communism (for better or for worse).

When liberals say that North Korea or some other regime they don't like doesn't represent the global community, what they're essentially saying is that these outsiders aren't human. Their community is the only legitimate community -- they alone represent the human race and the human condition.

But they don't. They have a specific set of ideological views from a specific place and time in history. Their human rights accusations amount to eyewitness journalism and stories that cannot be verified. Their narrative is one-sided, and their system is no better, no less absurd or ridiculous as any that's been operated by human beings. Westerners do not even believe in their leaders; they cannot for a moment believe that the tearful demonstrations at Il's funeral could possible be real. Their leaders are all shitty people who never do anything for them and like to hop aboard the lolita express. Contrast that with Kim Jong Un, a leader who actually refuses to back down to the international community. Obviously he loves his country and doesn't want to turn it into another grey, anti-culture Walmart dumping ground.

I cannot attest to the "greatness" of the Kim regime, but the point here is humility. You live under a fake system, you are no better. Your government commits war crimes every single day, for petty reasons.

Let's close this argument with George Carlin on rights:

https://youtu.be/m9-R8T1SuG4

Thank you

Their human rights accusations amount to eyewitness journalism and stories that cannot be verified. Their narrative is one-sided, and their system is no better, no less absurd or ridiculous as any that's been operated by human beings. Westerners do not even believe in their leaders; they cannot for a moment believe that the tearful demonstrations at Il's funeral could possible be real. Their leaders are all shitty people who never do anything for them and like to hop aboard the lolita express. Contrast that with Kim Jong Un, a leader who actually refuses to back down to the international community. Obviously he loves his country and doesn't want to turn it into another grey, anti-culture Walmart dumping ground.

I cannot attest to the "greatness" of the Kim regime, but the point here is humility. You live under a fake system, you are no better. Your government commits war crimes every single day, for petty reasons.

Let's close this argument with George Carlin on rights:

https://youtu.be/m9-R8T1SuG4

Thank you

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body: Who knows who any of these people really were, history has been rewritten so many times since then. Someone considered a villain now could've actually had their character assassinated by public opinion and we have no other records. In the same way an evil person who was idolized will have their story changed into being a very holy person, although this is usually easier to catch.

To be fair, some of the old saints also cause me great difficulty - I *want* to believe in Joan of Arc as a great godly woman who led the true believers to victory over the infidel Brits...and that it's just coincidence that her own army was the one to throw her in chains on charges of heathenry...

But I looked into it, both in the days before the web and the days since...and it gives me a very uneasy feeling

post.body:
In recent years, the Vatican 2 "popes" John XXIII, Paul VI, and John Paul II have all been canonized or made in to "saints". 

In context, in the last 500 years, of popes only Pope Pius V and Pope Pius X were made saints.

It sounds like they are trying to make Vatican 2 seem more legitimate, as if even to say that saints had called it in to session.

Canonizations are considered to be next to infallible - not absolutely infallible. Hence, if the Vatican 2 "popes" are popes, then it would seem almost absolute that Catholics must accept 3 of the Vatican 2 era "popes" are saints. If there is doubt or it is certain that such men are not saints, then it would seem to logically imply that the "pope" who canonized them is a "doubtful pope" or no pope.

Many problems have been brought up with the personal lives of these alleged "saints" that would make us at least doubt that they ought to have been canonized (not that they couldn't be saints, but it would seem doubtful that they ought to be publicly held up as examples of "heroic faith"). John XXIII was officially suspected of modernism by the Holy See; Paul VI controversially introduced the "New Mass" in 1969; John Paul II participated in the scandalous ecumenical 1986 Assisi meeting. Thus it would seem possible for them to have saved their souls, but doubt is introduced that they ought to be canonized.

In the process of canonizing a saint, traditionally the "Devil's Advocate" would argue for why they ought not be a saint. Yet, "Pope" John Paul II ["reduced the power and changed the role of the office in 1983."](https://infogalactic.com/info/Devil%27s_advocate) Therefore, it would seem that by doing this, it would be more likely for people to be "canonized" who are not saints, or it would increase the doubt about such canonizations being valid.

[One SSPX writer noted the contradiction of John Paul II being "canonized":](https://sspx.org/en/news-events/news/dilemma-canonizing-pope-john-paul-ii-3298)

> If John Paul II is truly a saint, the Catholic faithful must recognize that after the final resurrection, God will be satisfied with the Moslems and they will be satisfied with Him[5]. They must then condemn the example of the Capuchin Joseph of Leonessa (1556-1612) who worked without counting the cost in Constantinople among Christians reduced to slavery by the followers of Islam. His zeal caused him to be dragged before the sultan for insulting the Moslem religion and he spent three days hung from a set of gallows by a chain attached to hooks in one hand and one foot. Faithful Catholics should also deplore the example of St. Peter Mavimenus, who died in 715 after being tortured for three days for having insulted Mohammed and Islam.

John Paul II on this topic, stated:

> I believe that we, Christians and Moslems, we must recognize with joy the religious values that we have in common and give thanks to God. (…) We believe that God will be a merciful judge at the end of time and we hope that after the resurrection He will satisfied with us, and that we will be satisfied with Him." John Paul II, translated from the French version of his Address on the occasion of meeting young people at the stadium of Casablanca, August 18, 1985, DC 1903, p. 945. 

Hence, these contradictions suggest there is doubt that John Paul II should have been canonized, and therefore there is doubt that "pope" Francis (who "canonized" him) is a true Catholic pope. 

This is one topic that suggests sedevacantism is true.

What do you think about this problem of modern "canonizations"?

body: In fact Christianity and the new leftist, authoritarian brand of "conservatism" that only cares about enforcing "traditional values" are mutually exclusive because they contradict each other on nearly every point. Those who claim both labels are really only the latter holding onto the former because it's considered traditional. They are more inclined to agree with non-Christians who follow this mindset than other Christians who disagree, which is really alarming.
